msContents.summary: This bundle contains three folios wrapped with a piece of paper indicating that they were found with Sanscrit 1339. Although all three folios are of a similar size and format, there seem to be two manuscripts here — the first, 1442.7a, which contains a dharmaśāstra text, and the second, 1442.7b, which contains excerpts from the Mokṣadharmaparvan.

summary.p: This single folio contains a short treatise on inheritance in case there is no male heir. In its form and content, it mirrors chapter 17 of the Vaiṣṇavadharmaśāstra, to which it may be a commentary. However, this manuscript contains much more detail. In the Vaiṣṇavadharmaśāstra, the property of a man with no male heir goes to his wife, then daughter, then father, then mother, then brother, then a brother's son. In this manuscript, more subcategories are enumerated — for example, the term brother's son has been expanded to a uterine brother's son, then a half-brother's son, then a brother's grandson (folio 1r, lines 2-3).

One important divergence in this manuscript is that it allows for the sisters of the deceased to inherit property, in the absence of a brother's grandson (bhrātuṣputrasya putraḥ tadabhāve bhaginī, folio 1r, line 3), which was not traditionally sanctioned.

The Bālambhaṭṭī (Lakṣmīvyākhyāna) commentary on the Mitākṣarā, notably, does argue for the right of a sister to inherit, by interpreting bhrātaraḥ as an ekaśeṣa compound to mean brothers and sisters, or, more specifically, sisters, in case there are no brothers (bhrātā tadabhāve svasā, ed. Setlur 1914, 775), but this was a disputed point in the Anglo-Indian courts of law, and explicitly rejected in the Vyavahāramayūkha (ed. Kane 1926, 142).

Another text that seems to argue for the right of a sister to inherit is the Vivādaratnākara of Caṇḍeśvara. Commenting on a verse from the now lost Devalasmṛti, Caṇḍeśvara interprets tulyā duhitaro, equal daughters, to mean tulyāḥ sodaryyāḥ (ed. Smṛtitīrtha 1931, 599), which Setlur translates as uterine sisters (1911, 233). This may not have been Devala's intention, though; rather, he may have been referring to a daughter being equal to a son — putreṇa duhitā samā (Mānavadharmaśāstra 9.130, ed. Olivelle 2005, 770) — when a sonless man makes his daughter a "female son" (putrikā). Wadekar's reconstruction of the Devalasmṛti reads kulyā duhitaro (1996, 215) here.

In any case, what sets this manuscript apart from the two aforementioned texts as well as from traditional law is how it states, as a simple matter of fact, that sisters may inherit. It does not attempt to interpret a traditional text nor give any arguments for the rights of sisters; it simply includes them in the line of succession.

summary.p: These two folios in Bengali script contain two excerpts from the Śāntiparvan (book 12) of the Mahābhārata. The first folio begins mokṣadharme bhṛgubharadvājasaṃvāde, indicating that it contains a conversation between Bhṛgu and Bharadvāja from the Mokṣadharmaparvan, the last part of the book. The second folio has a similar marginal heading, mokṣe bhṛgubharadvājasaṃvāde.

The first folio, numbered 1, contains an excerpt from chapters 181-182 (following the critical edition), outlining how the four classes are distinguished. The beginning of verse 182.6 has the variant reading viśaty āśu paśubhyaś ca, which is found in Devanāgarī manuscripts of the text of Arjunamiśra and Nīlakaṇṭha, but not in the "Bengali Version" as collated by Sukthankar & Belvalkar in their edition.

The second folio, unfoliated and only written on one side, is from the end of chapter 201 (following the critical edition), in which the ṛṣi-s of the four cardinal directions are enumerated. This manuscript omits verse 33 and the first half of verse 34. This is perhaps an eyeskip due to the similarity between the beginning of verse 33, ete, and the beginning of verse 34c, eteṣāṃ.
